Award.AwardTitle: CI-P: Towards a Consensus Representation for Understanding Structure of Multiparty Conversations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Meetings provide unique knowledge sharing opportunities and are an efficient way of interaction between people with different expertise areas. Such human communication in stored audio form has rapidly grown in recent years, providing ample source material for later use. In particular, the increased prominence of search as a basic user activity has meant that the ability to automatically browse, summarize, or graphically visualize various aspects of the spoken content has become far more important. There are several studies on representation and detection of various types of events in multiparty conversations, such as agreement/disagreements and decisions. However, there is no consensus on how to represent structure of meeting discussions, to be used later for human browsing or in further automatic processing, such as summarization.

This planning project works towards a research infrastructure for a better understanding of meeting structure, and aims to organize a community effort in the form of a workshop, to identify the consensus needs of the meeting processing research and education community, for enhancing the existing and widely used ICSI meetings corpus with annotations of structure of meeting discussions. Such annotations are critical in initiating research on automatic detection and annotation of meeting discussions, and would also be useful for research on meeting visualization, browsing and summarization. Furthermore, such an infrastructure would provide students and researchers in natural language and speech processing a framework to experiment with and enable social scientists interested in interactional structures to develop more robust analysis mechanisms. The workshop discussions will contribute to the decision on an annotation schema and the design of annotation guidelines, with a small set of sample annotated meetings, which will be made publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Meetings are an extremely important part of modern life, affecting everything from hiring and firing decisions to which patients are given surgery. And yet there is no general, efficient mechanism for recording meetings so that we can browse them, track the status of discussion items later, or effectively and efficiently represent the structure of meetings for human browsing or automatic meeting processing. Most meetings have no recording except for manually written subjective notes about

action items and decisions. While there are a number of studies about representing and detecting events in multiparty conversations, such as action items, agreements/disagreements, and decisions, the spoken language research community has not yet reached a consensus on how to represent meeting structure.

The primary activity for this project was hosting a workshop on dialog annotation of meetings, including a literature review and two small annotations, one before and one as a follow-up to the meeting. There was no clear agreement either in the literature or among the workshop participants on how best to annotate meeting dialog. Particularly contentious was the question of how similar meetings are to other dialog. The participants broadly agreed that further annotation of meetings and other discourse types is necessary to answer these questions. As a result, we later produced a further small annotation of the ICSI Meeting Corpus. In this effort, we had annotators mark utterances as being either a statement or a question, with or without context, and via test or via text and audio. This was clearly a small pilot study from which few significant conclusions could be drawn. But we did observe that inter-annotator agreement was modest (about 80%), particularly for greater available context. Furthermore, the greater the context, the worse the agreement between annotators. This might be explained by an observed over-assignment of utterances to the Statement category for text-only annotation, so that there were more random agreements between the annotators.

The workshop, the associated pilot studies, and their results can only be viewed as a beginning to the study of the most promising directions for annotation of conversations from meetings. The prior collection and annotation of meeting data in the U.S. and in Europe (for the ICSI and AMI meeting corpora respectively) were much larger efforts, and contributed much more to the infrastructure necessary for the study of meetings. However, there were some observations in our pilot study that modified our previous understanding of the nature of the dialog in meetings.

As far as potential contributions across disciplines are concerned, some of the insights achieved could potentially affect research in downstream applications of annotated meeting data, such as speech recognition and metadata extraction.
